Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High-Performance Self-Cleaning, Anti-Reflective Coating for Photovoltaic Glass
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to reduce the cost of solar generated electricity by increasing the efficiency of panels and reducing cleaning and maintenance costs. This improvement is created using a multi-functional, nanoscale glass coating that increases the transmittance of solar photovoltaic glass and creates a surface that is antifogging and self-cleaning. Current anti-reflective coated glass has seen market penetration of only 25%, indicating a need for a top-performing, cheap, high-throughput coating. The implementation of this coating increase power output and reduce cost per watt. These savings increase with photovoltaic device efficiencies as well, so as the next generation of solar cells will see even greater benefit from the proposed innovation. Reducing the cost per watt of solar generated electricity is one of the grand energy challenges and has immense societal and governmental impacts. The proposed project is one component of addressing that challenge.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 1 project investigates the utilization of thermal and chemical processes to increase the durability of a anti-reflective solar glass coating. Nanoparticle-based antireflective glass coatings have been presented in both the scientific literature and commercial products. However, the only coatings with durability suitable for solar applications suffer from low performance. In this project, methods to increase the durability of a low-cost, high-performance nanoparticle coating through chemical and thermal processing are explored. The effect of chemical and thermal processing on the durability and reliability will be measured using a battery of industry standard tests. The failure mechanisms for these coatings will be investigated to further guide process optimization. A solar panel will then be assembled using the coated glass and benchmarked against an identical panel with uncoated glass. The expected outcome of this work is a solar panel that passes all standard reliability tests and demonstrates a significant increase in power output over a non-coated panel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Phase I and Phase IB funding received by WattGlass was critical in transitioning our coating technology from microscope slides to full scale solar PV modules. We made critical scientific discoveries that led to a next-generation coating that out performs all other antireflective coatings on the market, while also providing self-cleaning and anti-fogging capabilities.

 

Intellectual Merit

The conducted study was a comprehensive investigation of the optical properties of silica nanoparticle porous thin-films deposited from water-based non-toxic coating solutions. The self-cleaning ability and long-term stability of the coating’s superhydrophilicity was also investigated by fabricating 3 full scale solar modules that are installed in a roof-top test bed. The unique deposition method utilized in this study allowed for a tunable index of refraction and film thickness. This customization allowed for the production of ideal antireflective films. A method of maintaining this performance even on glass that is tempered at up to 750?C after being coated was developed.  The outcome of this study provided further understanding of the self-assembly of nanoparticles during wet-deposition steps from colloidal solutions and the influence of processing parameters on the optical properties of the film.

 

Broader Impacts

Production of electricity from alternative energy sources is one of the biggest challenges facing our society in this decade. To date, solar electricity is much more expensive to produce than electricity from fossil fuel sources. This project investigated a coating technology that could reduce the cost-per-watt of solar electricity by up to 5%. The knowledge generated is applicable to future, as well as current, solar panel designs. The project also interfaced with ongoing research at the University of Arkansas and collaborated with 3 graduate students. This exposure to research in a small business helps to train students in photovoltaic device production and optimization and prepare them for entry into either professional or academic career paths.
